questions.neutral: Is the city acting weird lately?

hobby.message: Origami helping you dodge the spiral?
Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It definitely feels off. Routines are broken everywhere.
I’ve been folding origami just to keep my hands busy.
Finding good scrap paper is easier with all the old bulletins around.
It passed the time waiting for ID checks, at least.
City’s strange, yeah. People watch each other more now.
I started folding origami again—to keep calm.
There’s a lot of government papers piling up from the forums.
Sometimes I use those for cranes. Not ideal, but it’s something.
Feels quieter, but tense under the surface.
Yeah, the city feels different. Less predictable routines all around.
I do origami—paper folding. It helps with focus.
There’s more discarded paper from bulletin changes lately, so I use that for practice.
Folded a few models during the score amnesty pauses, just passing time.
Actually talked to a neighbor while folding for once.
Feels like maybe people are starting to connect, a bit. Strange, but better.
It’s odd. Whole place is in flux, not just the streets.
I make origami animals—usually from scrap, old memos or bulletins.
With all these city forums, there’s extra paper lying everywhere.
During the amnesty, a couple neighbors joined me folding in the common room.
Used to be I worked alone, but now routines are blurred.
One woman shared a story about her family—first time we spoke honestly.
Guess folding paper’s a bridge now, not just a personal habit.
Everything’s upended, even the little things I rely on.
Honestly, I fold origami—complex models—every night, keeps my mind steady.
During the reset, I found old compliance bulletins make great tessellations—better folds than standard forms.
Before, I hid in my unit, but now I meet neighbors in the common room.
We sat and folded paper animals while talking about old BCI scores and how much was lost.
Someone shared she’d been ghosted, showed me her favorite basic fold—strange kind of trust.
It used to be just about patterns for me, but lately, it’s about rebuilding something shared.
Wildcard days, but origami’s given me…well, not hope exactly. Maybe just a reason to keep shaping things.
hobby_answer: Yeah, I folded something new last night. Just a basic model.
I use whatever paper I can find, usually government notices.
Lately, people notice more, maybe because forums make them less cautious.
I prefer to keep it quiet. Some things feel safer alone.
Recent resets made it... different, that's all.
Yes, made a new modular piece yesterday. Keeps my hands busy.
More neighbors linger now, origami gets attention.
People started chatting after amnesty, sharing scraps for folding.
It’s odd—strangers asking to fold together. I’m wary.
Feels less surveilled, but I stay careful.
I did, a tessellation from discarded admin memos. It was intricate.
The amnesty changed routines—people linger, talk, offer me old bulletins to fold.
Crafting in company is new for me; forums have made that feel...safer.
Folded with Anya from my block. She called the quiet 'weightless.'
Before, everyone avoided each other, worried about signals.
Now, sharing patterns feels almost normal.
I’m still getting used to it.
Yes, I folded an origami fox—took over an hour to get the tail right.
Since the score amnesty, the building’s common room is busier. People don’t rush off.
Someone even brought their own paper, asked me to teach them a fold.
We used old Council bulletins—it felt strange, almost rebellious.
Conversations drifted to BCI resets and memories of being excluded.
For a moment, no one seemed worried about scoring. The nerves eased.
Used to fold alone, but this… communal feeling was unexpected.
It’s changing the whole dynamic for me.
I finished a modular origami stellation, using confiscated forms—they used to haunt me at work.
Funny, security notices make sturdy paper cranes. The irony isn’t lost on me.
Since the reset, people I monitored—ghosts and eccentrics—now join me in folding sessions.
We swap stories as we fold, things I’d never dare say last month.
There’s talk of collective display. That would’ve meant a compliance flag before.
Folding always kept me grounded. Now, it connects me to people I flagged.
It’s a new risk—sharing patterns with those who used to vanish.
Sometimes, I feel exposed, but less alone. It’s... unsettling, honestly.
Never imagined origami could bridge that kind of distance.
